Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Materials and Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This REU site, based in the Physics Department of the University of Missouri, Columbia, will train 10 undergraduate student interns per summer in the area of materials experiments and modeling, broadly defined. The program will be targeted at junior and senior undergraduate students with Physics Majors, with the aim of introducing them to cutting-edge scientific research by engaging them in active and established research groups and motivating them to pursue a career in the sciences. Student research topics may be chosen from a broad area of materials physics (theoretical, experimental, or computational). Some examples are: theory of electronic structure in solids, spin-orbit interaction in oxide interfaces, simulation of RNA folding, tunable single electron memory, study of membrane proteins with atomic force microscopy, charge transport in transistors, neutron and x-ray scattering in solids, quantum spin ice systems, graphene and beyond-graphene materials, etc. While each student will work on a sharply focused area of research, they will gain a broader perspective of materials research from weekly discussions and presentations by their peers. In addition to their research, students will participate in weekly group meetings, attend weekly lectures in popular science as well as in general education topics such as scientific writing, ethics, and career opportunities in science and technology. Other planned activities include a visit to an industrial research and development facility. All students will be required to present their results as oral presentations at the MU Undergraduate Summer Research Day held each August and will be encouraged to participate in journal publications.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Students who complete this program will experience the reality of cutting-edge research in materials physics and engineering. This will enable them to understand their own level of aptitude and interest in a career in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) and give them the tools to prepare for the next stage in their education and career development. A diverse population of students will be recruited from the community colleges and undergraduate institutions in Missouri as well as nationally. The emphasis will be on students who might otherwise have limited access to research work and who in the absence of this experience might not pursue higher education or STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided exciting physics research experiences for 42 undergraduate students during the summers from 2014-2018. Working with physics professors at the University of Missouri, these summer interns helped further our understanding in a broad range of fields spanning astrophysics, nanophysics, and biophysics.

Their investigations in material science could potentially lead to new, useful technology solutions for society. Here are a few examples of students’ research projects and how the public could someday benefit:

  • Developing gold nanoparticles (potentially useful as new treatments for prostate cancer patients)
  • Measuring hydrogen gas storage in graphene (potentially useful as an alternative fuel technology)
  • Measuring voltage across organic semiconductors (potentially useful in developing flexible electronics)

This program recruited a diverse group of students to advance our knowledge in material sciences. Interns came from 23 institutions across the country, many from colleges and universities with limited research opportunities. These were bright students, with an average GPA of 3.72. Their demographic make-up met or exceeded national averages for underrepresented minorities and women in physics. These physics interns worked within the larger diverse science community of summer interns led by MU Office of Undergraduate Research program. During the funding period for this project, the MU summer program hosted 348 undergraduates, 48% of whom were female, and 30% of whom were underrepresented minorities (African-American, Hispanic, or Native American).

The Physics REU program prepared students for careers in advanced science and engineering fields. 26 of the 36 graduates reached have since started a PhD or MS program in physics or a related field; another 7 are filling greatly needed positions in science, such as softeware engineering or teaching. 93% of participants rated their physics summer research experience as “excellent” or “very good”. They were provided extensive professional development (e.g. research ethics, science seminars, graduate school information, networking events). The program also exposed students to careers outside of academia, with well-received annual tours of the MU Research Reactor and the Jordan Valley Innovation Center.

All interns (except one, who had to leave early) presented their work in poster format for a general audience, thus improving their communication skills. Many went on to present their work at conferences in Arizona, California, Florida, Missouri, Virginia, and Washington. So far, MU Physics faculty have co-authored with the REU participants:

  • 3 published articles
  • at least 3 more publications in preparation
  • 15 presentations at national or regional meetings

In summary, the program provided cutting-edge, authentic research experience to undergraduate students across the country. We especially tried to reach students who, without this experience, might not have otherwise pursued higher education or science careers. The project will help in building the future national work force to meet our growing technical needs.
